metadata.title: Synthesis and evaluation of poly octanediol citrate / nano silica composite

sections.text:
2214-7853 © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. Selection and/or Peer-review under responsibility of Biomedical and Advanced Materials (Biocam 2017).
For some applications of implantable polymeric devices, material degradation and disappearance with time is necessary. In such a case, control in the polymer applications can be achieved through understanding the process of degradation. Heat effect on physical changes of polymeric materials under service condition should also not be overlooked. Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite was developed and tested for glass transition (Tg) and physical degradation within the environmental factors that impact the use of the Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite for medical application. Degradation correlated well with the nano silica content while the indicated low Tg value confirmed the amorphousness of the Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite at 37°C. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. Selection and/or Peer-review under responsibility of Biomedical and Advanced Materials (Biocam 2017).
Keywords: Poly octanediol citrate; Bone fracture plate; Nanosilica

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Developing advanced materials for biomedical applications is one of the challenges facing modern materials. The potential use of biodegradable polymers has stimulated its development with various biodegradable elastomers been developed [1-3] despite the complexity of the synthesis procedure and the high cost of production. That hindered most of them from clinical applications and commercialisation.
* Corresponding author. Tel.: +60195638254. E-mail address: puteris@utp.edu.my
1970 Abdullahi Mahmud et al. / Materials Today: Proceedings 16 (2019) 1969–1975
Biodegradable citric acid based polyester have been employed in various tissue engineering applications with optimal physio-chemical properties [4, 5]. Ease of processing procedures that can be performed under mild conditions with the inclusion of no any toxic catalysts or crosslinking reagent, lower cost, proven biomimetic properties, controlled elastomeric behaviour, and tunable degradation rate have made Poly octanediol citrate (POC), a citric acid based polyester, a suitable choice in biomedical applications [6]. Possibilities of tailoring physical and chemical properties of POC was due to the retained carboxyl and hydroxyl of the citric acid.
POC was investigated for applications like myocardial tissue, vascular graft, and drug delivery due to its biomimetic viscoelastic behaviour [7, 8]. Cross-linked POC was characterised by low mechanical properties especially at the hydrated condition with the value much lower than that of bone tissues [9]. Despite the fast degradation rate, the accompanied low osteoconductive and osteoinductive properties hindered the use of virgin POC in bone tissue repair and regeneration without any enhancement.
Enhancement of mechanical properties of crosslinked POC has been tried by incorporating such an inorganic nano fillers like hydroxyapatite into POC matrix [10, 11]. However, physical mixing mechanism and poor physical interactions between the reinforcing filler and the polymer induced much concern for both the elastomeric behaviour and sti ness improvement.
Bone organic portion composed of 5.5%wt citrates [12], therefore citrate moieties emanating from POC may have a significant biological role when employed for bone composite and can help in rebuilding bone homeostasis [12, 13]. POC is the polymer of interest in this research, and as described by Yang et al. [14], its synthesis involved melting equimolar amounts of octanol and citric acid by reflux reaction under an inert atmosphere.
Biocompatibility, and high osteoconductive and osteoinductive properties have accorded silica-based biomaterials high clinical success for bone tissue repair [15, 16], which is attributed to the interaction of the silica silanol groups with the calcium and phosphate ions in biological fluids within the body. Nano silica as polymer reinforcement could be dispersed within the polymer matrix as silicate nano-layers with high aspect ratio.
Production of polymer nanocomposites has been extensively accomplished by direct compounding method because of its convenience, comparable cost, and massive production potentiality. Both the polymer and nanofiller were first prepared independently and after that compounded by mechanical forces, emulsion, solution, or fusion [17-22].
Polymers used in the production of implantable medical devices have the stability and integrity of the polymer over the predetermined period of the application as paramount. Implantable devices usually contact tissues whose essential component is water. Thus, their performance under use conditions can be influenced by the absorbed water. Synergistic property of composites requires strong bonding of the constituents if the constituents are hydrophilic, the absorbed water enriched at the interface with accompanied delamination of the components.
Thermal properties of polymers can adequately be determined by Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), a tool for the analysis of the glass transition, crystallisation, and melting temperatures. Apart from being simple and universal, Calorimetry measurement of energy characteristics depicts a clear physical meaning although interpretation may sometimes be difficult [23].
The paper reports the synthesis and evaluation of Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite based on the percentage nano silica loading and distribution regarding thermal analysis for glass transition (Tg), and in vitro degradation behaviour regarding weight loss percentage of the developed Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite.

sections.heading: 2.1. Production of Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite samples
sections.text:
The Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composites were developed by thorough mixing of the POC prepolymer and nano silica with the aid of mechanical stirrer to compound the mixture to clay-like. The mixture was postpolymerised by casting in Teflon moulds and curing for three days at 80°C and another two days at 120°C.
Equimolar amounts of octanol (98%) and of molar mass (146.23 g/mol) obtained from Sigma Aldrich and citric acid of high purity (99.5 – 100.5) and molar mass (192.124 g/mol) purchased from Merck, were mixed and reacted under an inert atmosphere of nitrogen gas. Melting of the mixture by reflux reaction proceeded at 160°C for 30 min
Abdullahi Mahmud et al. / Materials Today: Proceedings 16 (2019) 1969–1975 1971
under constant stirring for complete melting and reaction of the monomers. Gradual decrease of the temperature to 140°C followed afterwards, which was held for 60 min for the POC prepolymer to be produced. It was subsequently cooled to room temperature.
The nano silica used in this formulation was produced from rice husk by chemical treatment and calcination at 973K as reported by Mahmud et al. [24, 25]. High purity (99.761%) and high surface area (234.638 m2/g) with amorphous structure were the characteristics of the nano silica. It was used in the composite formulation at a concentration level of 20, 30, 40, 50, and 60%wt of the prepolymer with the composite being designated POC2SiO2, POC-3SiO2, POC-4SiO2, POC-5SiO2, and POC-6SiO2 hereafter.
The density of the developed Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composites was determined by using a balance produced by Mettler Toledo, which incorporates a kit for determination of density in conformity with Archimedes’ principle with the employed auxiliary fluid been distilled water. The cross-link density, n, was computed by the rubber elasticity theory from Equation-1 [26, 27].
c
o MRT E n  3
(1)
Where n is representing the number of active network chain segments per unit volume in mol./m3; Mc, molecular weight between cross-links in g/mol.; E0, Young’s modulus in Pascal; R, universal gas constant in J/mol.K; T, the absolute temperature in Kelvin; and ρ, elastomer density in g/m3 as determined by the method mentioned above.

sections.heading: 2.2. Thermal analysis of the Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite
sections.text: Differential scanning calorimetry was used for the thermal analysis of the developed Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composites. Sample specimens were sealed into standard DSC aluminium pans and tested under nitrogen purge (50ml/min). DSC was analysed between -50°C and 150°C at 10°C/min rate of heating. The composite sample specimens were first heated up to 150°C (first scan), then cooled down to -50°C and after that heated up again to 150°C (second scan). The glass transition temperature was halfway the step change of the recorded heat capacity in the second heating run.

sections.heading: 2.3. In vitro degradation of the Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite
sections.text:
Biodegradation plays an essential role in choosing materials for biomedical applications. The relative degradation rate of the developed Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite was evaluated in vitro by immersing the composite sample specimens in Phosphate buffered saline (PBS), a salt solution employed in biological research which is water-based with the ionic concentration matching that of the human body within the physiological range.
The composite sample specimens (10mm x 2mm) were put in 15ml centrifuge tubes containing a PBS with 7.4±0.2 pH value. The sample specimens were then incubated at 37°C for one, two, three, and four weeks and washed with distilled water at the set intervals to remove the saline. The sample specimens were oven dried afterwards to a constant weight. The weight loss of the sample specimens was noted as a percentage (%) by comparing the weight before incubation (Wb) with the weight after incubation (Wa) at given set interval as shown in Equation-2. The weight loss percentage was plotted against the time intervals.
%100loss weight Percentage  b ab W WW
(2)
1972 Abdullahi Mahmud et al. / Materials Today: Proceedings 16 (2019) 1969–1975

sections.heading: 3.1. Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite
sections.text:
Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite was successfully developed. Based on the given formulations, increasing quantities of nano silica were incorporated into the Poly octanediol citrate matrix. The cured composite sample specimens are as shown in Figure-1.
The density of the cured Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite samples increased gradually with the increasing weight per cent of the nano silica content within the composite (Table-1).
Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite samples designated POC–2SiO2 have lower density value of 1.1831 g/cm3 as compared to that of POC–6SiO2 which have 1.4055 g/cm3. This increment in density might be explained by a higher percentage of the nano silica contained within the composite.

sections.heading: 3.2. Glass transition temperature of the Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite
sections.text:
DSC thermograms showed thermal analysis for the glass transition temperatures of the developed Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite samples in Figure-2.
Abdullahi Mahmud et al. / Materials Today: Proceedings 16 (2019) 1969–1975 1973
Glass transition temperatures for all thermograms of the scanned sample specimens were below 37°C. Melting peaks or crystallisation peaks were not noticed in the thermograms. The indicated low Tg of the DSC analysis revealed that Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite is amorphous at 37°C, the expected operating temperature when used to produce bone fracture plate. Chain mobility of the polymer have a direct linkage to the Tg. Glass transition temperature increased when the restriction of polymer chain mobility was enhanced.

sections.heading: 3.3. Weight Loss of the Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite
sections.text:
The profile of Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite samples incubated at 37°C in PBS due to weight loss over time is as shown in Figure-3. Certain polymers weaken by hydrolysis reaction. Poly octanediol citrate hydrolytic degradation within the composite with subsequent loss of nano silica from the composite caused the composite to lose weight. Functions and in vivo integration of the composite used for a biomedical application would be influenced by the per cent weight and the degradation rate of the Poly octanediol citrate polymer component.
1974 Abdullahi Mahmud et al. / Materials Today: Proceedings 16 (2019) 1969–1975
At week 4, the Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite samples designated POC–2SiO2, POC–3SiO2, POC–4SiO2, POC–5SiO2, and POC–6SiO2 had weight losses of 31.76, 29.62, 21.01, 18.15, and 18.92% respectively. As could be noticed from Figure-3, nano silica content within the composite played an essential role in weight loss at all the time. Decreased degradation rate regarding weight loss was associated with increasing nano silica content of the nanocomposite. The degradation rates of the composites with 50 and 60 silica weight percentages were close at the set time intervals. POC-2SiO2 had the highest rate of degradation within week 4 of incubation while POC-6SiO2 showed the lowest rate.
Hydrolysis and enzymolysis of ester bonds can easily invoke degradation of Poly octanediol citrate polyester under physiological conditions [28]. The presence of hydrophilic groups such as hydroxyls and carboxyls have accorded water molecules ease of penetrating the Poly octanediol citrate network and hydrolysing the ester bonds.
The lower rates of degradation seen with the Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composites should be attributed to the different polycondensation degree of reaction because of the limited weight percentage of the Poly octanediol citrate and the inclusion of the nano silica in the composites. The degree of crosslinking, for the same curing temperature and time, is expected to be affected as such.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this investigation poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composites containing 20, 30, 40, 50, and 60%wt nano silica were developed. Effect of increasing nano silica content on the thermal property and physical degradation of the composite was investigated. Dependence of the degradation kinetics on nano silica content within the nanocomposite was evident as faster degradation correlated with the decrease in nano silica content. The low Tg value indicated by DSC analysis confirmed that the Poly octanediol citrates/Nano silica composite is entirely amorphous at 37°C, the expected operating temperature when used to produce bone fracture plate. The development of Poly octanediol citrate/Nano silica composite should add to the repertoire of the existing biodegradable composite in meeting the biomedical application requirements for implantable devices.
Abdullahi Mahmud et al. / Materials Today: Proceedings 16 (2019) 1969–1975 1975
